intro: Microula trichocarpa var. trichocarpa, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family, characterized by its succulent, fleshy stems and leaves adapted to conserve water. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, typically blooming in spring. Its root system is extensive, allowing it to anchor in loose, sandy soils and access deep water sources. The species is well-suited to harsh environments, making it an important component of desert ecosystems.
